titleInfo.title: Low Self-Control, Neighborhood Collective Efficacy, and Child Development as Explanations of Victimization

name.namePart: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
College of Criminology and Criminal Justice

mods:mods.abstract: A wealth of research has documented the association between low self-control and child victimization. However, the conditions under which low self-control has the greatest impact on victimization have rarely been examined and, more importantly, no prior research has examined the complex ways in which neighborhood characteristics interact with self-control and other individual characteristics to impact victimization. Using data from the Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods, the current study tests whether the effect of low self-control is contingent upon age and poverty and whether the positive effect of low self-control on victimization is lessened in neighborhoods with high collective efficacy. Furthermore, this study goes beyond the prior literature by examining the multifaceted nature of conditional effects. By employing three-level multivariate Rasch models and cross-level three-way interactions, the research demonstrates that low self-control increases the risk of victimization, and that the effect of low self-control depends on the combined effects of neighborhood collective efficacy of children, age, and poverty. Thus, this study claims that child victimization is a product of the complicated interplay between neighborhood context—child-based collective efficacy—and children's individual characteristics—low self-control, age, and poverty. This study advances our understanding of the specific conditions and situations where low self-control most significantly influences victimization, emphasizing the intricate nature of conditional effects. This research contributes importantly to building a developmental and life-course perspective on victimization. In addition, by forging new pathways in understanding the multifaceted influences on victimization, this research paves the way for innovative strategies in prevention and intervention, ultimately contributing to more effective and holistic approaches to addressing victimization across the lifespan.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Criminology and Criminal Justice in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Brian J. Stults, Professor Directing Dissertation; Miles G. Taylor, University Representative; Carter Hay, Committee Member; Julie Brancale, Committee Member.

etd:degree.etd:name: Doctor of Philosophy
etd:degree.etd:discipline: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
